Clockwise from top left: [Berlin Cathedral](/wiki/Berlin_Cathedral "Berlin Cathedral"), [New Synagogue](/wiki/New_Synagogue_(Berlin) "New Synagogue (Berlin)"), [Şehitlik Mosque](/wiki/%C5%9Eehitlik_Mosque "Şehitlik Mosque"), and [St. Hedwig's Cathedral](/wiki/St._Hedwig%27s_Cathedral "St. Hedwig's Cathedral")

On the report of the 2011 census, approximately 37 percent of the population reported being members of a legally-recognized church or religious organization. The rest either did not belong to such an organization, or there was no information available about them.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-121)^{#cite_ref-121}

The largest religious denomination recorded in 2010 was the [Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant") [regional church body](/wiki/Landeskirche "Landeskirche")---the [Evangelical Church of Berlin-Brandenburg-Silesian Upper Lusatia (EKBO)](/wiki/Evangelical_Church_of_Berlin-Brandenburg-Silesian_Upper_Lusatia "Evangelical Church of Berlin-Brandenburg-Silesian Upper Lusatia")---a [united church](/wiki/United_church "United church"). EKBO is a member of the [Protestant Church in Germany (EKD)](/wiki/Protestant_Church_in_Germany "Protestant Church in Germany") and of the [Union of Protestant Churches in the EKD (UEK)](/wiki/Union_of_Protestant_Churches_in_the_EKD "Union of Protestant Churches in the EKD"). According to the EKBO, their membership accounted for 18.7 percent of the local population, while the [Roman Catholic Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") had 9.1 percent of residents registered as its members.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-122)^ About 2.7% of the population identify with other Christian denominations (mostly [Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church"), but also various Protestants).^[\[123\]](#cite_note-Amt_für_Statistik_Berlin–Brandenburg-2010-123)^ According to the Berlin residents register, in 2018 14.9 percent were members of the Evangelical Church, and 8.5 percent were members of the Catholic Church.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-Amt_für_Statistik_Berlin-Brandenburg-104)^ The government keeps a register of members of these churches for tax purposes, because it collects [church tax](/wiki/Church_tax#Germany "Church tax") on behalf of the churches. It does not keep records of members of other religious organizations which may collect their own church tax, in this way.{#cite_ref-Amt_für_Statistik_Berlin-Brandenburg_104-3}

In 2009, approximately 249,000 [Muslims](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") were reported by the [Office of Statistics](/wiki/Amt_f%C3%BCr_Statistik_Berlin-Brandenburg "Amt für Statistik Berlin-Brandenburg") to be members of mosques and Islamic religious organizations in Berlin,^[\[124\]](#cite_note-124)^ while in 2016, the newspaper *[Der Tagesspiegel](/wiki/Der_Tagesspiegel "Der Tagesspiegel")* estimated that about 350,000 Muslims observed [Ramadan](/wiki/Ramadan "Ramadan") in Berlin.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-Ramadan-125)^ In 2019, about 437,000 registered residents, 11.6% of the total, reported having a migration background from one of the [Member states of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation](/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Organization_of_Islamic_Cooperation "Member states of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation").^[\[104\]](#cite_note-Amt_für_Statistik_Berlin-Brandenburg-104)^^[\[125\]](#cite_note-Ramadan-125)^ Between 1992 and 2011 the Muslim population almost doubled.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-126)^{#cite_ref-126}

About 0.9% of Berliners belong to other religions. Of the estimated population of 30,000--45,000 Jewish residents,^[\[127\]](#cite_note-127)^ approximately 12,000 are registered members of religious organizations.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-Amt_für_Statistik_Berlin–Brandenburg-2010-123)^{#cite_ref-Amt_für_Statistik_Berlin–Brandenburg-2010_123-1}

Berlin is the seat of the [Roman Catholic archbishop of Berlin](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Berlin "Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Berlin") and [EKBO](/wiki/Evangelical_Church_of_Berlin-Brandenburg-Silesian_Upper_Lusatia "Evangelical Church of Berlin-Brandenburg-Silesian Upper Lusatia")'s elected chairperson is titled the bishop of EKBO. Furthermore, Berlin is the seat of many Orthodox cathedrals, such as the Cathedral of St. Boris the Baptist, one of the two seats of the [Bulgarian Orthodox](/wiki/Bulgarian_Orthodox_Church "Bulgarian Orthodox Church") Diocese of Western and Central Europe, and the Resurrection of Christ Cathedral of the Diocese of Berlin (Patriarchate of Moscow).

The faithful of the different religions and denominations maintain many [places of worship in Berlin](/wiki/List_of_places_of_worship_in_Berlin "List of places of worship in Berlin"). The [Independent Evangelical Lutheran Church](/wiki/Independent_Evangelical_Lutheran_Church "Independent Evangelical Lutheran Church") has eight parishes of different sizes in Berlin.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-128)^ There are 36 [Baptist](/wiki/Baptist "Baptist") congregations (within [Union of Evangelical Free Church Congregations in Germany](/wiki/Union_of_Evangelical_Free_Church_Congregations_in_Germany "Union of Evangelical Free Church Congregations in Germany")), 29 [New Apostolic Churches](/wiki/New_Apostolic_Church "New Apostolic Church"), 15 [United Methodist](/wiki/United_Methodist "United Methodist") churches, eight Free Evangelical Congregations, four [Churches of Christ, Scientist](/wiki/Church_of_Christ,_Scientist "Church of Christ, Scientist") (1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 11th), six congregations of [the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints](/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints "The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints"), an [Old Catholic](/wiki/Old_Catholic "Old Catholic") church, and an [Anglican](/wiki/Anglican "Anglican") church in Berlin. Berlin has more than 80 mosques,^[\[129\]](#cite_note-129)^ ten synagogues,^[\[130\]](#cite_note-130)^ and two [Buddhist](/wiki/Buddhist "Buddhist") as well as four [Hindu](/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism") temples.{#cite_ref-130}  

Government and politics {#Government_and_politics}
--------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Government and politics")\]  
Main articles: [Politics of Berlin](/wiki/Politics_of_Berlin "Politics of Berlin") and [Berlin Police](/wiki/Berlin_Police "Berlin Police")  

### German federal city state {#German_federal_city_state}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: German federal city state")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/At_Berlin_2024_263.jpg/220px-At_Berlin_2024_263.jpg)](/wiki/File:At_Berlin_2024_263.jpg) [Rotes Rathaus](/wiki/Rotes_Rathaus "Rotes Rathaus") (*Red City Hall*), seat of the Senate and Mayor of Berlin

Since the [German reunification](/wiki/German_reunification "German reunification") on 3 October 1990, Berlin has been one of the three city-[states of Germany](/wiki/States_of_Germany "States of Germany") among the present 16 federal states of Germany. The [Abgeordnetenhaus von Berlin](/wiki/Abgeordnetenhaus_von_Berlin "Abgeordnetenhaus von Berlin") (*House of Representatives* ) functions as the city and state parliament, which has 141 seats. Berlin's executive body is the [Senate of Berlin](/wiki/Senate_of_Berlin "Senate of Berlin") (*Senat von Berlin* ). The Senate consists of the [Governing Mayor of Berlin](/wiki/Governing_Mayor_of_Berlin "Governing Mayor of Berlin") (*Regierender Bürgermeister* ), and up to ten senators holding ministerial positions, two of them holding the title of "Mayor" (*Bürgermeister* ) as deputy to the Governing Mayor.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-131)^{#cite_ref-131}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Charlottenburg_Otto-Suhr-Allee_Rathaus_Charlottenburg-001.jpg/220px-Charlottenburg_Otto-Suhr-Allee_Rathaus_Charlottenburg-001.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charlottenburg_Otto-Suhr-Allee_Rathaus_Charlottenburg-001.jpg) [Charlottenburg Town Hall](/wiki/Charlottenburg_Town_Hall "Charlottenburg Town Hall") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Bahnhof_Spandau_Nacht_1.jpg/220px-Bahnhof_Spandau_Nacht_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bahnhof_Spandau_Nacht_1.jpg) [Rathaus Spandau](/wiki/Rathaus_Spandau "Rathaus Spandau")

The total annual budget of Berlin in 2015 exceeded €24.5 ($30.0) billion including a budget surplus of €205 ($240) million.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-132)^ The German Federal city state of Berlin owns extensive assets, including administrative and government buildings, real estate companies, as well as stakes in the Olympic Stadium, swimming pools, housing companies, and numerous public enterprises and subsidiary companies.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-133)^^[\[134\]](#cite_note-134)^ The federal state of Berlin runs a real estate portal to advertise commercial spaces or land suitable for redevelopment.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-135)^{#cite_ref-135}

The [Social Democratic Party](/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany "Social Democratic Party of Germany") (SPD) and [The Left](/wiki/The_Left_(Germany) "The Left (Germany)") (Die Linke) took control of the city government after the [2001 state election](/wiki/Berlin_state_election,_2001 "Berlin state election, 2001") and won another term in the [2006 state election](/wiki/Berlin_state_election,_2006 "Berlin state election, 2006").^[\[136\]](#cite_note-136)^ From the [2016 state election](/wiki/Berlin_state_election,_2016 "Berlin state election, 2016") until the [2023 state election](/wiki/2023_Berlin_state_election "2023 Berlin state election"), there was a coalition between the Social Democratic Party, the Greens and the Left Party. Since April 2023, the government has been formed by a coalition between the Christian Democrats and the Social Democrats.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-Kai_Wegner_zum_Regierenden_Bürgermeister_von_Berlin_gewählt-2023-137)^{#cite_ref-Kai_Wegner_zum_Regierenden_Bürgermeister_von_Berlin_gewählt-2023_137-0}

The Governing Mayor is simultaneously Lord Mayor of the City of Berlin (*Oberbürgermeister der Stadt* ) and Minister President of the State of Berlin (*Ministerpräsident des Bundeslandes* ). The office of the Governing Mayor is in the [Rotes Rathaus (Red City Hall)](/wiki/Rotes_Rathaus "Rotes Rathaus"). Since 2023, this office has been held by [Kai Wegner](/wiki/Kai_Wegner "Kai Wegner") of the Christian Democrats.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-Kai_Wegner_zum_Regierenden_Bürgermeister_von_Berlin_gewählt-2023-137)^ He is the first conservative mayor in Berlin in more than two decades.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-138)^{#cite_ref-138}  

### Boroughs {#Boroughs}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Boroughs")\]  
Main article: [Boroughs and neighborhoods of Berlin](/wiki/Boroughs_and_neighborhoods_of_Berlin "Boroughs and neighborhoods of Berlin")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Berlin_Subdivisions.svg/290px-Berlin_Subdivisions.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Berlin_Subdivisions.svg) [Berlin's 12 boroughs and their 96 neighborhoods](/wiki/Boroughs_and_neighborhoods_of_Berlin "Boroughs and neighborhoods of Berlin")

Berlin is subdivided into 12 boroughs or districts (*Bezirke* ). Each borough has several subdistricts or neighborhoods (*Ortsteile* ), which have roots in much older municipalities that predate the formation of Greater Berlin on 1 October 1920. These subdistricts became urbanized and incorporated into the city later on. Many residents strongly identify with their neighborhoods, colloquially called *[Kiez](/wiki/Kiez "Kiez")* . At present, Berlin consists of 96 subdistricts, which are commonly made up of several smaller residential areas or quarters.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

Each borough is governed by a borough council (*Bezirksamt* ) consisting of five councilors (*Bezirksstadträte* ) including the borough's mayor (*Bezirksbürgermeister* ). The council is elected by the borough assembly (*Bezirksverordnetenversammlung* ). However, the individual boroughs are not independent municipalities, but subordinate to the Senate of Berlin.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ The borough's mayors make up the council of mayors (*Rat der Bürgermeister*), which is led by the city's Governing Mayor and advises the Senate. The neighborhoods have no local government bodies.  

### City partnerships {#City_partnerships}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: City partnerships")\]  
Main article: [List of twin towns and sister cities in Germany](/wiki/List_of_twin_towns_and_sister_cities_in_Germany "List of twin towns and sister cities in Germany")

Berlin to this day maintains official partnerships with 17 cities.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-139)^ [Town twinning](/wiki/Sister_city "Sister city") between [West Berlin](/wiki/West_Berlin "West Berlin") and other cities began with its sister city Los Angeles, California, in 1967. [East Berlin](/wiki/East_Berlin "East Berlin")'s partnerships were canceled at the time of [German reunification](/wiki/German_reunification "German reunification").{#cite_ref-139}  

### Capital city {#Capital_city}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Capital city")\]

Berlin is the capital of the Federal Republic of Germany. The [President of Germany](/wiki/President_of_Germany "President of Germany"), whose functions are mainly ceremonial under the [German constitution](/wiki/Grundgesetz "Grundgesetz"), has their official residence in [Bellevue Palace](/wiki/Bellevue_Palace_(Germany) "Bellevue Palace (Germany)").^[\[140\]](#cite_note-140)^ Berlin is the [seat](/wiki/Seat_of_government "Seat of government") of the [German Chancellor](/wiki/Chancellor_of_Germany_(1949%E2%80%93) "Chancellor of Germany (1949–)") (Prime Minister), housed in the [Chancellery building](/wiki/Federal_Chancellery_(Berlin) "Federal Chancellery (Berlin)"), the *Bundeskanzleramt* . Facing the Chancellery is the [Bundestag](/wiki/Bundestag "Bundestag"), the German Parliament, housed in the renovated [Reichstag building](/wiki/Reichstag_building "Reichstag building") since the government's relocation to Berlin in 1998. The [Bundesrat](/wiki/Bundesrat_of_Germany "Bundesrat of Germany") ("federal council", performing the function of an [upper house](/wiki/Upper_house "Upper house")) is the [representation](/wiki/Federalism "Federalism") of the [16 constituent states](/wiki/States_of_Germany "States of Germany") (*Länder* ) of Germany and has its seat at the former [Prussian House of Lords](/wiki/Prussian_House_of_Lords "Prussian House of Lords"). The total annual federal budget managed by the German government exceeded €310 ($375) billion in 2013.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-141)^{#cite_ref-141}

  The [Federal Chancellery building](/wiki/Federal_Chancellery_(Berlin) "Federal Chancellery (Berlin)"), seat of the [Chancellor of Germany](/wiki/Chancellor_of_Germany_(1949%E2%80%93) "Chancellor of Germany (1949–)")
  * [![The Reichstag, seat of the Bundestag](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Berlin_reichstag_west_panorama.jpg/399px-Berlin_reichstag_west_panorama.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin_reichstag_west_panorama.jpg "The Reichstag, seat of the Bundestag")

  [Prussian House of Lords](/wiki/Prussian_House_of_Lords "Prussian House of Lords"), seat of the [Bundesrat of Germany](/wiki/Bundesrat_of_Germany "Bundesrat of Germany")

  [Headquarters of the Federal Intelligence Service](/wiki/Headquarters_of_the_Federal_Intelligence_Service "Headquarters of the Federal Intelligence Service")

The relocation of the federal [government](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Germany "Cabinet of Germany") and Bundestag to Berlin was mostly completed in 1999. However, some ministries, as well as some minor departments, stayed in the [federal city](/wiki/Federal_city "Federal city") [Bonn](/wiki/Bonn "Bonn"), the former capital of West Germany. [Discussions about moving](/wiki/Berlin-Bonn_Act "Berlin-Bonn Act") the remaining ministries and departments to Berlin continue.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-142)^{#cite_ref-142}

The [Federal Foreign Office](/wiki/Foreign_Office_(Germany) "Foreign Office (Germany)") and the ministries and departments of [Defense](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Defence_(Germany) "Federal Ministry of Defence (Germany)"), [Justice and Consumer Protection](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Justice_and_Consumer_Protection "Federal Ministry of Justice and Consumer Protection"), [Finance](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Finance_(Germany) "Federal Ministry of Finance (Germany)"), [Interior](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Germany) "Federal Ministry of the Interior (Germany)"), [Economic Affairs and Energy](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_for_Economic_Affairs_and_Energy_(Germany) "Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (Germany)"), [Labor and Social Affairs](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Labour_and_Social_Affairs "Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs"), [Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Family_Affairs,_Senior_Citizens,_Women_and_Youth "Federal Ministry of Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth"), [Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_the_Environment,_Nature_Conservation_and_Nuclear_Safety "Federal Ministry of the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety"), [Food and Agriculture](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Food_and_Agriculture "Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture"), [Economic Cooperation and Development](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_for_Economic_Cooperation_and_Development "Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development"), [Health](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Health_(Germany) "Federal Ministry of Health (Germany)"), [Transport and Digital Infrastructure](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Transport_and_Digital_Infrastructure "Federal Ministry of Transport and Digital Infrastructure") and [Education and Research](/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Education_and_Research_(Germany) "Federal Ministry of Education and Research (Germany)") are based in the capital.  

### Embassies {#Embassies}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Embassies")\]

Berlin hosts in total 158 foreign embassies^[\[143\]](#cite_note-143)^ as well as the headquarters of many think tanks, trade unions, nonprofit organizations, lobbying groups, and professional associations. Frequent official visits and diplomatic consultations among governmental representatives and national leaders are common in contemporary Berlin.{#cite_ref-143}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
Main article: [Economy of Berlin](/wiki/Economy_of_Berlin "Economy of Berlin")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Blue_Hour_in_Berlin.jpg/220px-Blue_Hour_in_Berlin.jpg)](/wiki/File:Blue_Hour_in_Berlin.jpg) Berlin is a UNESCO "City of Design" and recognized for its [creative industries](/wiki/Creative_industries "Creative industries") and [startup ecosystem](/wiki/Startup_ecosystem "Startup ecosystem").^[\[144\]](#cite_note-144)^

In 2018, the GDP of Berlin totaled €147 billion, an increase of 3.1% over the previous year.^[\[3\]](#cite_note-Amt_für_Statistik_Berlin-Brandenburg-2-3)^ Berlin's economy is dominated by the [service sector](/wiki/Service_sector "Service sector"), with around 84% of all companies doing business in services. In 2015, the total labor force in Berlin was 1.85 million. The unemployment rate reached a 24-year low in November 2015 and stood at 10.0%.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-145)^ From 2012 to 2015 Berlin, as a German state, had the highest annual employment growth rate. Around 130,000 jobs were added in this period.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-146)^{#cite_ref-146}

Important economic sectors in Berlin include life sciences, transportation, information and communication technologies, media and music, advertising and design, biotechnology, environmental services, construction, e-commerce, retail, hotel business, and medical engineering.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-147)^{#cite_ref-147}

Research and development have economic significance for the city.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-berlin.de-148)^ Several major corporations like [Volkswagen](/wiki/Volkswagen "Volkswagen"), [Pfizer](/wiki/Pfizer "Pfizer"), and [SAP](/wiki/SAP "SAP") operate innovation laboratories in the city.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-149)^ The Science and Business Park in Adlershof is the largest technology park in Germany measured by revenue.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-150)^ Within the [eurozone](/wiki/Eurozone "Eurozone"), Berlin has become a center for business relocation and international [investments](/wiki/Investment_(macroeconomics) "Investment (macroeconomics)").^[\[151\]](#cite_note-151)^{#cite_ref-151}
