### Companies {#Companies}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Companies")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/DBBuildingBerling150809.jpg/132px-DBBuildingBerling150809.jpg)](/wiki/File:DBBuildingBerling150809.jpg)  
[Deutsche Bahn](/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn"), the largest railway company in the world,^[\[153\]](#cite_note-Fortune-153)^ is headquartered in Berlin.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Berlin%2C_Mitte%2C_Behrenstrasse%2C_Berliner_Bank_05.jpg/206px-Berlin%2C_Mitte%2C_Behrenstrasse%2C_Berliner_Bank_05.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin,_Mitte,_Behrenstrasse,_Berliner_Bank_05.jpg)  
[Deutscher Sparkassen- und Giroverband](/wiki/Deutscher_Sparkassen-_und_Giroverband "Deutscher Sparkassen- und Giroverband"), the European Union's second-largest financial services group, has its headquarters in Berlin.

Many German and international companies have business or service centers in the city. For several years Berlin has been recognized as a major center of [business founders](/wiki/Entrepreneurship "Entrepreneurship").^[\[154\]](#cite_note-154)^ In 2015, Berlin generated the most venture capital for young [startup companies](/wiki/Startup_company "Startup company") in Europe.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-155)^{#cite_ref-155}

Among the 10 largest employers in Berlin are the City-State of Berlin, [Deutsche Bahn](/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn"), largest railway company in the world,^[\[153\]](#cite_note-Fortune-153)^ the hospital providers [Charité](/wiki/Charit%C3%A9 "Charité") and [Vivantes](/wiki/Vivantes "Vivantes"), the Federal Government of Germany, the local public transport provider [BVG](/wiki/Berliner_Verkehrsbetriebe "Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe"), [Siemens](/wiki/Siemens "Siemens") and [Deutsche Telekom](/wiki/Deutsche_Telekom "Deutsche Telekom").^[\[156\]](#cite_note-156)^{#cite_ref-156}

Siemens, a [Global 500](/wiki/Fortune_Global_500 "Fortune Global 500") and [DAX](/wiki/DAX "DAX")-listed company is partly headquartered in Berlin. Other DAX-listed companies headquartered in Berlin are the property company [Deutsche Wohnen](/wiki/Deutsche_Wohnen "Deutsche Wohnen") and the online food delivery service [Delivery Hero](/wiki/Delivery_Hero "Delivery Hero"). The national railway operator [Deutsche Bahn](/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn"),^[\[157\]](#cite_note-157)^ Europe's largest digital publisher^[\[158\]](#cite_note-158)^ [Axel Springer](/wiki/Axel_Springer_SE "Axel Springer SE") as well as the [MDAX](/wiki/MDAX "MDAX")-listed firms [Zalando](/wiki/Zalando "Zalando") and [HelloFresh](/wiki/HelloFresh "HelloFresh") and also have their main headquarters in the city. Among the largest international corporations who have their German or European headquarters in Berlin are [Bombardier Transportation](/wiki/Bombardier_Transportation "Bombardier Transportation"), [Securing Energy for Europe](/wiki/Securing_Energy_for_Europe "Securing Energy for Europe"), [Coca-Cola](/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca-Cola"), [Pfizer](/wiki/Pfizer "Pfizer"), [Sony](/wiki/Sony "Sony") and [TotalEnergies](/wiki/TotalEnergies "TotalEnergies").{#cite_ref-158}

As of 2023, [Sparkassen-Finanzgruppe](/wiki/Sparkassen-Finanzgruppe "Sparkassen-Finanzgruppe"), a network of [public banks](/wiki/Public_bank "Public bank") that together form the largest financial services group in Germany and in all of Europe, is headquartered in Berlin. The [Bundesverband der Deutschen Volksbanken und Raiffeisenbanken](/wiki/Bundesverband_der_Deutschen_Volksbanken_und_Raiffeisenbanken "Bundesverband der Deutschen Volksbanken und Raiffeisenbanken") has its headquarters in Berlin, managing around 1.200 trillion euros.^[\[159\]](#cite_note-159)^ The three largest banks in the capital are [Deutsche Kreditbank](/wiki/Deutsche_Kreditbank "Deutsche Kreditbank"), [Landesbank Berlin](/wiki/Landesbank_Berlin "Landesbank Berlin") and [Berlin Hyp](/wiki/Berlin_Hyp "Berlin Hyp").^[\[160\]](#cite_note-160)^{#cite_ref-160}

[Mercedes-Benz Group](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Group "Mercedes-Benz Group") manufactures cars, and [BMW builds motorcycles](/wiki/BMW_Motorrad "BMW Motorrad") in Berlin. In 2022, American electric car manufacturer [Tesla](/wiki/Tesla,_Inc. "Tesla, Inc.") opened its first European Gigafactory outside the city borders in [Grünheide (Mark)](/wiki/Gr%C3%BCnheide_(Mark) "Grünheide (Mark)"), Brandenburg. The Pharmaceuticals division of [Bayer](/wiki/Bayer "Bayer")^[\[161\]](#cite_note-161)^ and [Berlin Chemie](/wiki/Berlin_Chemie "Berlin Chemie") are major pharmaceutical companies in the city.{#cite_ref-161}  

### Tourism and conventions {#Tourism_and_conventions}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Tourism and conventions")\]  
Main article: [List of tourist attractions in Berlin](/wiki/List_of_tourist_attractions_in_Berlin "List of tourist attractions in Berlin")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Berlin_Fashion_Week_2013_b.jpg/206px-Berlin_Fashion_Week_2013_b.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin_Fashion_Week_2013_b.jpg)  
[Berlin Fashion Week](/wiki/Berlin_Fashion_Week "Berlin Fashion Week")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/IFA_2012_IMG_7677.JPG/206px-IFA_2012_IMG_7677.JPG)](/wiki/File:IFA_2012_IMG_7677.JPG)  
[IFA](/wiki/Internationale_Funkausstellung_Berlin "Internationale Funkausstellung Berlin") is one of Europe's leading trade shows for consumer electronics.

Berlin had 788 hotels with 134,399 beds in 2014.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-visitBerlin-162)^ The city recorded 28.7 million overnight hotel stays and 11.9 million hotel guests in 2014.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-visitBerlin-162)^ Tourism figures have more than doubled within the last ten years and Berlin has become the third-most-visited city destination in Europe. Some of the most visited places in Berlin include: [Potsdamer Platz](/wiki/Potsdamer_Platz "Potsdamer Platz"), [Brandenburger Tor](/wiki/Brandenburg_Gate "Brandenburg Gate"), [the Berlin wall](/wiki/Berlin_Wall "Berlin Wall"), [Alexanderplatz](/wiki/Alexanderplatz "Alexanderplatz"), [Museumsinsel](/wiki/Museum_Island "Museum Island"), [Fernsehturm](/wiki/Fernsehturm_Berlin "Fernsehturm Berlin"), the [East-Side Gallery](/wiki/East_Side_Gallery "East Side Gallery"), [Schloss-Charlottenburg](/wiki/Charlottenburg_Palace "Charlottenburg Palace"), [Zoologischer Garten](/wiki/Berlin_Zoological_Garden "Berlin Zoological Garden"), [Siegessäule](/wiki/Berlin_Victory_Column "Berlin Victory Column"), [Gedenkstätte Berliner Mauer](/wiki/Gedenkst%C3%A4tte_Berliner_Mauer "Gedenkstätte Berliner Mauer"), [Mauerpark](/wiki/Mauerpark "Mauerpark"), [Botanical Garden](/wiki/Berlin-Dahlem_Botanical_Garden_and_Botanical_Museum "Berlin-Dahlem Botanical Garden and Botanical Museum"), [Französischer Dom](/wiki/French_Cathedral,_Berlin "French Cathedral, Berlin"), [Deutscher Dom](/wiki/Deutscher_Dom "Deutscher Dom") and [Holocaust-Mahnmal](/wiki/Memorial_to_the_Murdered_Jews_of_Europe "Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe"). The largest visitor groups are from Germany, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Italy, Spain and the United States.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-visitBerlin_162-1}

According to figures from the [International Congress and Convention Association](/wiki/International_Congress_and_Convention_Association "International Congress and Convention Association") in 2015, Berlin became the leading organizer of conferences globally, hosting 195 international meetings.^[\[163\]](#cite_note-163)^ Some of these congress events take place on venues such as CityCube Berlin or the Berlin Congress Center (bcc).{#cite_ref-163}

The [Messe Berlin](/wiki/Messe_Berlin "Messe Berlin") (also known as Berlin ExpoCenter City) is the main convention organizing company in the city. Its main exhibition area covers more than 160,000 square meters (1,722,226 sq ft). Several large-scale trade fairs like the consumer electronics trade fair [IFA](/wiki/IFA_Berlin "IFA Berlin"), where the first practical audio [tape recorder](/wiki/Magnetophon "Magnetophon") and the first [completely electronic television system](/wiki/Manfred_von_Ardenne "Manfred von Ardenne") were first introduced to the public,^[\[164\]](#cite_note-164)^^[\[165\]](#cite_note-165)^^[\[166\]](#cite_note-166)^^[\[167\]](#cite_note-167)^ the [ILA Berlin Air Show](/wiki/ILA_Berlin_Air_Show "ILA Berlin Air Show"), the [Berlin Fashion Week](/wiki/Berlin_Fashion_Week "Berlin Fashion Week") (including the *Premium Berlin* and the *Panorama Berlin* ),^[\[168\]](#cite_note-168)^ the [Green Week](/wiki/Berlin_International_Green_Week "Berlin International Green Week"), the *Fruit Logistica* , the transport fair [InnoTrans](/wiki/InnoTrans "InnoTrans"), the tourism fair [ITB](/wiki/ITB_Berlin "ITB Berlin") and the adult entertainment and erotic fair [Venus](/wiki/Venus_Award "Venus Award") are held annually in the city, attracting a significant number of business visitors.{#cite_ref-168}  

### Creative industries {#Creative_industries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Creative industries")\]  
For a more comprehensive list, see [List of films set in Berlin](/wiki/List_of_films_set_in_Berlin "List of films set in Berlin").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/European_Film_Academy_-_European_Film_Awards_logo.svg/220px-European_Film_Academy_-_European_Film_Awards_logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:European_Film_Academy_-_European_Film_Awards_logo.svg) The [European Film Academy](/wiki/European_Film_Academy "European Film Academy") (logo pictured) was founded in Berlin. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Postfuhramt_%28Berlin%29_-msu-2021-4274-.jpg/220px-Postfuhramt_%28Berlin%29_-msu-2021-4274-.jpg)](/wiki/File:Postfuhramt_(Berlin)_-msu-2021-4274-.jpg) [Postfuhramt](/wiki/Postfuhramt "Postfuhramt") in Berlin-Mitte, where [Ottomar Anschütz](/wiki/Ottomar_Ansch%C3%BCtz "Ottomar Anschütz") held the first showing of life sized pictures in motion on 25 November 1894^[\[169\]](#cite_note-169)^

The [creative arts and entertainment](/wiki/Creative_industries "Creative industries") business is an important part of Berlin's economy. The sector comprises music, film, advertising, architecture, art, design, [fashion](/wiki/German_fashion "German fashion"), performing arts, publishing, [R\&D](/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development"), software,^[\[170\]](#cite_note-170)^ TV, radio, and [video games](/wiki/Video_gaming_in_Germany "Video gaming in Germany").{#cite_ref-170}

In 2014, around 30,500 creative companies operated in the Berlin-Brandenburg metropolitan region, predominantly [SMEs](/wiki/Small_and_medium-sized_enterprises "Small and medium-sized enterprises"). Generating a revenue of 15.6 billion Euro and 6% of all private economic sales, the culture industry grew from 2009 to 2014 at an average rate of 5.5% per year.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-171)^{#cite_ref-171}

Berlin is an important European and [German film industry](/wiki/Cinema_of_Germany "Cinema of Germany") hub.^[\[172\]](#cite_note-172)^ It is home to more than 1,000 film and television production companies, 270 movie theaters, and around 300 national and international co-productions are filmed in the region every year.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-berlin.de-148)^ The historic [Babelsberg Studios](/wiki/Babelsberg_Studios "Babelsberg Studios") and the production company [UFA](/wiki/Universum_Film_AG "Universum Film AG") are adjacent to Berlin in [Potsdam](/wiki/Potsdam "Potsdam"). The city is also home of the [German Film Academy](/wiki/Deutsche_Filmakademie "Deutsche Filmakademie") (Deutsche Filmakademie), founded in 2003, and the [European Film Academy](/wiki/European_Film_Academy "European Film Academy"), founded in 1988.{#cite_ref-berlin.de_148-1}  

### Media {#Media}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Media")\]  
Main article: [Media in Berlin](/wiki/Media_in_Berlin "Media in Berlin")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Axel-Springer-Neubau_Berlin%2C_1._Juli_2019_01.jpg/220px-Axel-Springer-Neubau_Berlin%2C_1._Juli_2019_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Axel-Springer-Neubau_Berlin,_1._Juli_2019_01.jpg) The new building of [Axel Springer SE](/wiki/Axel_Springer_AG "Axel Springer AG") which is headquartered in Berlin

Berlin is home to many magazine, newspaper, book, and scientific/academic publishers and their associated service industries. In addition, around 20 news agencies, more than 90 regional daily newspapers and their websites, as well as the Berlin offices of more than 22 national publications such as *[Der Spiegel](/wiki/Der_Spiegel "Der Spiegel")*, and [Die Zeit](/wiki/Die_Zeit "Die Zeit") reinforce the capital's position as Germany's epicenter for influential debate. Therefore, many international journalists, bloggers, and writers live and work in the city.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

Berlin is the central location to several international and regional television and radio stations.^[\[173\]](#cite_note-173)^ The public broadcaster [RBB](/wiki/Rundfunk_Berlin-Brandenburg "Rundfunk Berlin-Brandenburg") has its headquarters in Berlin as well as the commercial broadcasters [MTV Europe](/wiki/MTV_Europe "MTV Europe") and [Welt](/wiki/Welt_(German_TV_channel) "Welt (German TV channel)"). German international public broadcaster [Deutsche Welle](/wiki/Deutsche_Welle "Deutsche Welle") has its TV production unit in Berlin, and most national German broadcasters have a studio in the city, including [ZDF](/wiki/ZDF "ZDF") and [RTL](/wiki/RTL_Television "RTL Television").{#cite_ref-173}

Berlin has Germany's largest number of daily newspapers, with numerous local [broadsheets](/wiki/Broadsheet "Broadsheet") (*[Berliner Morgenpost](/wiki/Berliner_Morgenpost "Berliner Morgenpost")* , *[Berliner Zeitung](/wiki/Berliner_Zeitung "Berliner Zeitung")* , *[Der Tagesspiegel](/wiki/Der_Tagesspiegel "Der Tagesspiegel")* ), and three major [tabloids](/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format) "Tabloid (newspaper format)"), as well as national dailies of varying sizes, each with a different political affiliation, such as *[Die Welt](/wiki/Die_Welt "Die Welt")* , *[Neues Deutschland](/wiki/Neues_Deutschland "Neues Deutschland")* , and *[Die Tageszeitung](/wiki/Die_Tageszeitung "Die Tageszeitung")* . *[The Berliner](/wiki/The_Berliner_(magazine) "The Berliner (magazine)")* , a monthly magazine, is Berlin's English-language periodical and [La Gazette de Berlin](/wiki/La_Gazette_de_Berlin "La Gazette de Berlin") a French-language newspaper.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

Berlin is also the headquarter of major German-language publishing houses like [Walter de Gruyter](/wiki/Walter_de_Gruyter "Walter de Gruyter"), [Springer](/wiki/Axel_Springer_AG "Axel Springer AG"), the Ullstein Verlagsgruppe (publishing group), [Suhrkamp](/wiki/Suhrkamp "Suhrkamp"), and Cornelsen are all based in Berlin. Each of which publishes books, periodicals, and multimedia products.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  

Quality of life {#Quality_of_life}
----------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Quality of life")\]

According to [Mercer](/wiki/Mercer_(consulting_firm) "Mercer (consulting firm)"), Berlin ranked number 13 in the Quality of Living City Ranking in 2019.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-174)^{#cite_ref-174}

Also in 2019, according to [*Monocle*](/wiki/Monocle_(UK_magazine) "Monocle (UK magazine)"), Berlin occupied the position of the 6th-most-livable city in the world.^[\[175\]](#cite_note-175)^ [Economist Intelligence Unit](/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit "Economist Intelligence Unit") ranked Berlin number 21 of all global cities for *livability* .^[\[176\]](#cite_note-176)^ In 2019 Berlin was also number 8 on the Global Power City Index.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-177)^ In the same year Berlin was honored for having the best future prospects of all cities in Germany.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-178)^{#cite_ref-178}  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Transport")\]  
Main article: [Transport in Berlin](/wiki/Transport_in_Berlin "Transport in Berlin")  

### Roads {#Roads}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Roads")\]

Berlin's transport infrastructure provides a diverse range of urban mobility.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-179)^{#cite_ref-179}

A total of 979 bridges cross 197 km (122 miles) the inner-city waterways. Berlin roads total 5,422 km (3,369 miles) of which 77 km (48 miles) are motorways (known as [Autobahn](/wiki/Autobahn "Autobahn")).^[\[180\]](#cite_note-Amt_für_Statistik_Berlin_Brandenburg-180)^ In 2013 only 1.344 million motor vehicles were registered in the city.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-Amt_für_Statistik_Berlin_Brandenburg-180)^ With 377 cars per 1000 residents in 2013 (570/1000 in Germany), Berlin as a Western global city has one of the lowest numbers of cars per capita.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-181)^{#cite_ref-181}  

### Cycling {#Cycling}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Cycling")\]
[![Cyclists in Prenzlauer Berg, Berlin](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Berlin_Cycle_Tour.jpg/220px-Berlin_Cycle_Tour.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin_Cycle_Tour.jpg) Cyclists in Prenzlauer Berg, Berlin  
Main article: [Cycling in Berlin](/wiki/Cycling_in_Berlin "Cycling in Berlin")

Berlin is well known for its highly developed [bicycle lane](/wiki/Bicycle_lane "Bicycle lane") system.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-182)^ It is estimated that Berlin has 710 bicycles per 1,000 residents. Around 500,000 daily bike riders accounted for 13 percent of total traffic in 2010.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-183)^{#cite_ref-183}

Cyclists in Berlin have access to 620 km of bicycle paths including approximately 150 km of mandatory bicycle paths, 190 km of off-road bicycle routes, 60 km of bicycle lanes on roads, 70 km of shared bus lanes which are also open to cyclists, 100 km of combined pedestrian/bike paths and 50 km of marked bicycle lanes on roadside pavements or sidewalks.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-184)^ Riders are allowed to carry their bicycles on [Regionalbahn](/wiki/Regionalbahn "Regionalbahn") (RE), S-Bahn and U-Bahn trains, on trams, and on night buses if a bike ticket is purchased.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-185)^{#cite_ref-185}  

### Taxicabs {#Taxicabs}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Taxicabs")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Taxis_at_EDDT.jpg/220px-Taxis_at_EDDT.jpg)](/wiki/File:Taxis_at_EDDT.jpg) Mercedes-Benz taxicabs

Taxicabs in Berlin are yellow or beige. In 2024, around 8,000 [taxicabs](/wiki/Taxicabs "Taxicabs") were in service.^[\[186\]](#cite_note-186)^ Like in most of Europe, app-based [sharing cab services](/wiki/Ridesharing_company "Ridesharing company") are available but limited.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-187)^{#cite_ref-187}  

### Rail {#Rail}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Rail")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Train_station_Berlin_Potsdamer_Platz.jpg/220px-Train_station_Berlin_Potsdamer_Platz.jpg)](/wiki/File:Train_station_Berlin_Potsdamer_Platz.jpg) [DB](/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn") [Station Potsdamer Platz](/wiki/Berlin_Potsdamer_Platz_station "Berlin Potsdamer Platz station") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Berlin_Hauptbahnhof0514.JPG/220px-Berlin_Hauptbahnhof0514.JPG)](/wiki/File:Berlin_Hauptbahnhof0514.JPG) [Berlin Hauptbahnhof](/wiki/Berlin_Hauptbahnhof "Berlin Hauptbahnhof") (Berlin Central Station)

Long-distance rail lines directly connect Berlin with all of the major cities of Germany. the regional rail lines of the [Verkehrsverbund Berlin-Brandenburg](/wiki/Verkehrsverbund_Berlin-Brandenburg "Verkehrsverbund Berlin-Brandenburg") provide access to [Brandenburg](/wiki/Brandenburg "Brandenburg") and to the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea"). The [Berlin Hauptbahnhof](/wiki/Berlin_Hauptbahnhof "Berlin Hauptbahnhof") (Berlin Central Station) is the largest [grade-separated](/wiki/Grade_separation "Grade separation") railway station in Europe.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-188)^ The [Deutsche Bahn](/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn") runs the high speed [Intercity-Express](/wiki/Intercity-Express "Intercity-Express") (ICE) to domestic destinations, including [Hamburg](/wiki/Hamburg "Hamburg"), [Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich"), [Cologne](/wiki/Cologne "Cologne"), [Stuttgart](/wiki/Stuttgart "Stuttgart"), and [Frankfurt am Main](/wiki/Frankfurt_am_Main "Frankfurt am Main").{#cite_ref-188}  

### Water transport {#Water_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Water transport")\]

The [Spree](/wiki/Spree_(river) "Spree (river)") and the [Havel](/wiki/Havel "Havel") rivers cross Berlin. There are no frequent passenger connections to and from Berlin by water. Berlin's largest harbour, the [Westhafen](/wiki/Westhafen "Westhafen"), is located in the district of [Moabit](/wiki/Moabit "Moabit"). It is a transhipment and storage site for inland shipping with a growing importance.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-189)^{#cite_ref-189}  

### Intercity buses {#Intercity_buses}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Intercity buses")\]

There is an increasing quantity of [intercity bus services](/wiki/Intercity_bus_service "Intercity bus service"). Berlin city has more than 10 stations^[\[190\]](#cite_note-190)^ that run buses to destinations throughout Berlin. Destinations in Germany and Europe are connected via the intercity bus exchange *[Zentraler Omnibusbahnhof Berlin](/wiki/Zentraler_Omnibusbahnhof_Berlin "Zentraler Omnibusbahnhof Berlin")*.{#cite_ref-190}  

### Urban public transport {#Urban_public_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Urban public transport")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Berlin_-_U-Bahnhof_Heidelberger_Platz_S%C3%BCdzugang.jpg/220px-Berlin_-_U-Bahnhof_Heidelberger_Platz_S%C3%BCdzugang.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin_-_U-Bahnhof_Heidelberger_Platz_S%C3%BCdzugang.jpg) The Berlin U-Bahn (Metro) at [Heidelberger Platz station](/wiki/Berlin_Heidelberger_Platz_station "Berlin Heidelberger Platz station")

The *[Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe](/wiki/Berliner_Verkehrsbetriebe "Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe")* (BVG) and the German State-owned [Deutsche Bahn](/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn") (DB) manage several extensive urban public transport systems.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-191)^{#cite_ref-191}

|                                System                                |  Stations / Lines / Net length   |  Annual ridership  |                                                                  Operator / Notes                                                                  |
|            [S-Bahn](/wiki/Berlin_S-Bahn "Berlin S-Bahn")             |    166 / 16 / 331 km (206 mi)    | 431,000,000 (2016) | [DB](/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn") / Mainly overground [rapid transit](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") rail system with suburban stops |
|            [U-Bahn](/wiki/Berlin_U-Bahn "Berlin U-Bahn")             |     173 / 9 / 146 km (91 mi)     | 563,000,000 (2017) |           [BVG](/wiki/Berliner_Verkehrsbetriebe "Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe") / Mainly underground rail system / 24h-service on weekends            |
|  [Tram](/wiki/Tram_transport_in_Berlin "Tram transport in Berlin")   |    404 / 22 / 194 km (121 mi)    | 197,000,000 (2017) |                                                  BVG / Operates predominantly in eastern boroughs                                                  |
|    [Bus](/wiki/Bus_transport_in_Berlin "Bus transport in Berlin")    | 3227 / 198 / 1,675 km (1,041 mi) | 440,000,000 (2017) |                                             BVG / Extensive services in all boroughs / 62 Night Lines                                              |
| [Ferry](/wiki/Ferry_transport_in_Berlin "Ferry transport in Berlin") |             6 lines              |                    |                                                BVG / Transportation as well as recreational ferries                                                |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------|--------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|

Public transport in Berlin has a long and complicated history because of the 20th-century division of the city, where movement between the two halves was not served. Since 1989, the transport network has been developed extensively. However, it still contains early 20th century traits, such as the U1.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-192)^{#cite_ref-192}  

### Airports {#Airports}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Airports")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Berlin_Brandenburg_Airport_at_night.jpg/220px-Berlin_Brandenburg_Airport_at_night.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin_Brandenburg_Airport_at_night.jpg) [Berlin Brandenburg Airport](/wiki/Berlin_Brandenburg_Airport "Berlin Brandenburg Airport") (BER) at night

Berlin is served by one commercial international airport: [Berlin Brandenburg Airport](/wiki/Berlin_Brandenburg_Airport "Berlin Brandenburg Airport") (BER), located just outside Berlin's south-eastern border, in the state of Brandenburg. It began construction in 2006, with the intention of replacing [Tegel Airport](/wiki/Berlin_Tegel_Airport "Berlin Tegel Airport") (TXL) and [Schönefeld Airport](/wiki/Berlin_Sch%C3%B6nefeld_Airport "Berlin Schönefeld Airport") (SXF) as the single commercial airport of Berlin.^[\[193\]](#cite_note-193)^ Previously set to open in 2012, after extensive delays and cost overruns, it opened for commercial operations in October 2020.^[\[194\]](#cite_note-194)^ The planned initial capacity of around 27 million passengers per year^[\[195\]](#cite_note-195)^ is to be further developed to bring the terminal capacity to approximately 55 million per year by 2040.^[\[196\]](#cite_note-196)^{#cite_ref-196}

Before the opening of the BER in Brandenburg, Berlin was served by Tegel Airport and Schönefeld Airport. Tegel Airport was within the city limits, and Schönefeld Airport was located at the same site as BER. Both airports together handled 29.5 million passengers in 2015. In 2014, 67 airlines served 163 destinations in 50 countries from Berlin.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-197)^ Tegel Airport was a focus city for [Lufthansa](/wiki/Lufthansa "Lufthansa") and [Eurowings](/wiki/Eurowings "Eurowings") while Schönefeld served as an important destination for airlines like [Germania](/wiki/Germania_(airline) "Germania (airline)"), [easyJet](/wiki/EasyJet "EasyJet") and [Ryanair](/wiki/Ryanair "Ryanair"). Until 2008, Berlin was also served by the smaller [Tempelhof Airport](/wiki/Tempelhof_Airport "Tempelhof Airport"), which functioned as a city airport, with a convenient location near the city center, allowing for quick transit times between the central business district and the airport. The airport grounds have since been turned into a city park.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-197}  

Rohrpost {#Rohrpost}
--------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Rohrpost")\]  
Main article: [Rohrpost in Berlin](/wiki/Rohrpost_in_Berlin "Rohrpost in Berlin")

From 1865 to 1976, Berlin operated an expansive [pneumatic postal network](/wiki/Pneumatic_tube "Pneumatic tube"), reaching a maximum length of 400 kilometers (roughly 250 miles) by 1940. The system was divided into two distinct networks after 1949. The West Berlin system remained in public use until 1963, and continued to be utilized for government correspondence until 1972. Conversely, the East Berlin system, which incorporated the *Hauptelegraphenamt*---the central hub of the operation---remained functional until 1976.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  

Energy {#Energy}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Energy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Berlin-mitte_heizkraftwerk-mitte_20060605_629.jpg/220px-Berlin-mitte_heizkraftwerk-mitte_20060605_629.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin-mitte_heizkraftwerk-mitte_20060605_629.jpg) Heizkraftwerk Mitte power plant

Berlin's two largest energy provider for private households are the Swedish firm [Vattenfall](/wiki/Vattenfall "Vattenfall") and the Berlin-based company [GASAG](/wiki/GASAG "GASAG"). Both offer electric power and natural gas supply. Some of the city's electric energy is imported from nearby power plants in southern [Brandenburg](/wiki/Brandenburg "Brandenburg").^[\[198\]](#cite_note-198)^{#cite_ref-198}

As of 2015^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit)^ the five [largest power plants measured by capacity](/wiki/List_of_power_stations_in_Germany "List of power stations in Germany") are the Heizkraftwerk Reuter West, the Heizkraftwerk Lichterfelde, the Heizkraftwerk Mitte, the Heizkraftwerk Wilmersdorf, and the Heizkraftwerk Charlottenburg. All of these [power stations](/wiki/Power_station "Power station") generate [electricity](/wiki/Electricity_generation "Electricity generation") and [useful heat](/wiki/Heat "Heat") at the same time to facilitate buffering during load peaks.

In 1993 the power grid connections in the Berlin-Brandenburg capital region were renewed. In most of the inner districts of Berlin power lines are underground cables; only a 380 kV and a 110 kV line, which run from Reuter substation to the urban [Autobahn](/wiki/Autobahn "Autobahn"), use overhead lines. The [Berlin 380-kV electric line](/wiki/Berlin_380-kV_electric_line "Berlin 380-kV electric line") is the backbone of the city's energy grid.  

Health {#Health}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Health")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Charit%C3%A9_vom_Futurium_aus.jpg/220px-Charit%C3%A9_vom_Futurium_aus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charit%C3%A9_vom_Futurium_aus.jpg) [Charité](/wiki/Charit%C3%A9 "Charité")

Berlin has a long history of discoveries in medicine and innovations in medical technology.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-199)^ The modern history of medicine has been significantly influenced by scientists from Berlin. [Rudolf Virchow](/wiki/Rudolf_Virchow "Rudolf Virchow") was the founder of cellular pathology, while [Robert Koch](/wiki/Robert_Koch "Robert Koch") developed vaccines for anthrax, cholera, and tuberculosis.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-200)^ For his life's work Koch is seen as one of the founders of modern medicine.^[\[201\]](#cite_note-201)^{#cite_ref-201}

The [Charité](/wiki/Charit%C3%A9 "Charité") complex (Universitätsklinik Charité) is the largest [university hospital](/wiki/University_hospital "University hospital") in Europe, tracing back its origins to the year 1710. More than half of all German Nobel Prize winners in Physiology or Medicine, including [Emil von Behring](/wiki/Emil_von_Behring "Emil von Behring"), Robert Koch and [Paul Ehrlich](/wiki/Paul_Ehrlich "Paul Ehrlich"), have worked at the Charité. The Charité is spread over four campuses and comprises around 3,000 beds, 15,500 staff, 8,000 students, and more than 60 operating theaters, and it has a turnover of two billion euros annually.^[\[202\]](#cite_note-Charité_–_Universitätsmedizin_Berlin-202)^{#cite_ref-Charité_–_Universitätsmedizin_Berlin_202-0}  

Telecommunication {#Telecommunication}
--------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: Telecommunication")\]  
Main article: [Radio and telecommunication in Berlin](/wiki/Radio_and_telecommunication_in_Berlin "Radio and telecommunication in Berlin")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/St_oberholz.jpg/220px-St_oberholz.jpg)](/wiki/File:St_oberholz.jpg) Café customers in Berlin Mitte using [Wi-Fi](/wiki/Wi-Fi "Wi-Fi") devices

Since 2017, the [digital television](/wiki/Digital_television "Digital television") standard in Berlin and Germany is [DVB-T2](/wiki/DVB-T2 "DVB-T2"). This system transmits [compressed](/wiki/Video_compression "Video compression") [digital audio](/wiki/Digital_audio "Digital audio"), [digital video](/wiki/Digital_video "Digital video") and other data in an [MPEG transport stream](/wiki/MPEG_transport_stream "MPEG transport stream").

Berlin has installed several hundred free public [Wireless LAN](/wiki/Wireless_LAN "Wireless LAN") sites across the capital since 2016. The wireless networks are concentrated mostly in central districts; 650 hotspots (325 indoor and 325 outdoor access points) are installed.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-203)^{#cite_ref-203}

The [UMTS](/wiki/UMTS "UMTS") (3G) and [LTE](/wiki/LTE_(telecommunication) "LTE (telecommunication)") (4G) networks of the three major cellular operators [Vodafone](/wiki/Vodafone "Vodafone"), [Telekom Deutschland](/wiki/Telekom_Deutschland "Telekom Deutschland") and [O2](/wiki/Telef%C3%B3nica_Germany "Telefónica Germany") enable the use of mobile broadband applications citywide.  

Education and research {#Education_and_research}
------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: Education and research")\]  
Main article: [Education in Berlin](/wiki/Education_in_Berlin "Education in Berlin")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Berlin-Mitte_Humboldt-Uni_05-2014.jpg/220px-Berlin-Mitte_Humboldt-Uni_05-2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin-Mitte_Humboldt-Uni_05-2014.jpg) The [Humboldt University of Berlin](/wiki/Humboldt_University_of_Berlin "Humboldt University of Berlin"), the world's first modern university,^[\[204\]](#cite_note-204)^ is affiliated with 57 Nobel Prize winners.

As of 2014^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit)^, Berlin had 878 schools, teaching 340,658 students in 13,727 classes and 56,787 trainees in businesses and elsewhere.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-berlin.de-148)^ The city has a 6-year primary education program. After completing primary school, students continue to the *Sekundarschule* (a comprehensive school) or *Gymnasium* (college preparatory school). Berlin has a special bilingual school program in the *Europaschule*, in which children are taught the curriculum in German and a foreign language, starting in primary school and continuing in high school.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-205)^{#cite_ref-205}

The [Französisches Gymnasium Berlin](/wiki/Franz%C3%B6sisches_Gymnasium_Berlin "Französisches Gymnasium Berlin"), which was founded in 1689 to teach the children of Huguenot refugees, offers (German/French) instruction.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-206)^ The [John F. Kennedy School](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_School,_Berlin "John F. Kennedy School, Berlin"), a bilingual German--American public school in [Zehlendorf](/wiki/Zehlendorf_(Berlin) "Zehlendorf (Berlin)"), is particularly popular with children of diplomats and the English-speaking expatriate community. 82 *Gymnasien* teach [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin")^[\[207\]](#cite_note-207)^ and 8 teach [Classical Greek](/wiki/Classical_Greek "Classical Greek").^[\[208\]](#cite_note-208)^{#cite_ref-208}  

### Higher education {#Higher_education}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Higher education")\]  
Main article: [Universities and research institutions in Berlin](/wiki/Universities_and_research_institutions_in_Berlin "Universities and research institutions in Berlin")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Freie_Universitaet_Berlin_-_Gebaeudekomplex_Rost-_und_Silberlaube.jpg/220px-Freie_Universitaet_Berlin_-_Gebaeudekomplex_Rost-_und_Silberlaube.jpg)](/wiki/File:Freie_Universitaet_Berlin_-_Gebaeudekomplex_Rost-_und_Silberlaube.jpg) The [Free University of Berlin](/wiki/Free_University_of_Berlin "Free University of Berlin")

The Berlin-Brandenburg capital region is one of the most prolific centers of higher education and research in Germany and Europe. Historically, 67 Nobel Prize winners are affiliated with the Berlin-based universities.

The city has four public research universities and more than 30 private, professional, and technical colleges *(Hochschulen)* , offering a wide range of disciplines.^[\[209\]](#cite_note-209)^ A record number of 175,651 students were enrolled in the winter term of 2015/16.^[\[210\]](#cite_note-210)^ Among them around 18% have an international background.{#cite_ref-210}

The three largest universities combined have approximately 103,000 enrolled students. There are the [Freie Universität Berlin](/wiki/Free_University_of_Berlin "Free University of Berlin") *(Free University of Berlin, FU Berlin)* with about 33,000^[\[211\]](#cite_note-211)^ students, the [Humboldt Universität zu Berlin](/wiki/Humboldt_University_of_Berlin "Humboldt University of Berlin") *(HU Berlin)* with 35,000^[\[212\]](#cite_note-212)^ students, and [Technische Universität Berlin](/wiki/Technische_Universit%C3%A4t_Berlin "Technische Universität Berlin") *(TU Berlin)* with 35,000^[\[213\]](#cite_note-213)^ students. The [Charité](/wiki/Charit%C3%A9 "Charité") Medical School has around 8,000 students.^[\[202\]](#cite_note-Charité_–_Universitätsmedizin_Berlin-202)^ The FU, the HU, the TU, and the Charité make up the [Berlin University Alliance](/wiki/Berlin_University_Alliance "Berlin University Alliance"), which has received funding from the [Excellence Strategy](/wiki/German_Universities_Excellence_Initiative "German Universities Excellence Initiative") program of the German government.^[\[214\]](#cite_note-214)^^[\[215\]](#cite_note-215)^ The [Universität der Künste](/wiki/Berlin_University_of_the_Arts "Berlin University of the Arts") *(UdK)* has about 4,000 students and [ESMT Berlin](/wiki/ESMT_Berlin "ESMT Berlin") is only one of four business schools in Germany with [triple accreditation](/wiki/Triple_accreditation "Triple accreditation").^[\[216\]](#cite_note-216)^ The [Hertie School](/wiki/Hertie_School "Hertie School"), a private public policy school located in Mitte, has more than 900 students and doctoral students. The [Berlin School of Economics and Law](/wiki/Berlin_School_of_Economics_and_Law "Berlin School of Economics and Law") has an enrollment of about 11,000 students, the [Berlin University of Applied Sciences and Technology](/wiki/Berliner_Hochschule_f%C3%BCr_Technik "Berliner Hochschule für Technik") of about 12,000 students, and the [Hochschule für Technik und Wirtschaft](/wiki/HTW_Berlin "HTW Berlin") (University of Applied Sciences for Engineering and Economics) of about 14,000 students.{#cite_ref-216}  

### Research {#Research}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Research")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Berlin_Adlershof_Photonics_Center_2016.jpg/220px-Berlin_Adlershof_Photonics_Center_2016.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin_Adlershof_Photonics_Center_2016.jpg) The [WISTA Science and Technology Park](/w/index.php?title=WISTA_Science_and_Technology_Park&action=edit&redlink=1 "WISTA Science and Technology Park (page does not exist)") in [Adlershof](/wiki/Berlin-Adlershof "Berlin-Adlershof")

The city has a high density of internationally renowned research institutions, such as the [Fraunhofer Society](/wiki/Fraunhofer_Society "Fraunhofer Society"), the [DLR Institute for Planetary Research](/wiki/DLR_Institute_for_Planetary_Research "DLR Institute for Planetary Research"), the [Leibniz Association](/wiki/Leibniz_Association "Leibniz Association"), the [Helmholtz Association](/wiki/Helmholtz_Association_of_German_Research_Centres "Helmholtz Association of German Research Centres"), and the [Max Planck Society](/wiki/Max_Planck_Society "Max Planck Society"), which are independent of, or only loosely connected to its universities.^[\[217\]](#cite_note-217)^ In 2012, around 65,000 professional scientists were working in [research and development](/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development") in the city.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-berlin.de-148)^{#cite_ref-berlin.de_148-3}

Berlin is one of the knowledge and innovation communities (KIC) of the [European Institute of Innovation and Technology](/wiki/European_Institute_of_Innovation_and_Technology "European Institute of Innovation and Technology") (EIT).^[\[218\]](#cite_note-218)^ The KIC is based at the Center for Entrepreneurship at TU Berlin and has a focus in the development of IT industries. It partners with major multinational companies such as [Siemens](/wiki/Siemens "Siemens"), [Deutsche Telekom](/wiki/Deutsche_Telekom "Deutsche Telekom"), and [SAP](/wiki/SAP_SE "SAP SE").^[\[219\]](#cite_note-219)^{#cite_ref-219}

One of Europe's successful research, business and technology [clusters](/wiki/List_of_technology_centers "List of technology centers") is based at [WISTA](/wiki/WISTA "WISTA") in [Berlin-Adlershof](/wiki/Berlin-Adlershof "Berlin-Adlershof"), with more than 1,000 affiliated firms, university departments and scientific institutions.^[\[220\]](#cite_note-220)^{#cite_ref-220}

In addition to the university-affiliated libraries, the [Staatsbibliothek zu Berlin](/wiki/Staatsbibliothek_zu_Berlin "Staatsbibliothek zu Berlin") is a major research library. Its two main locations are on Potsdamer Straße and on [Unter den Linden](/wiki/Unter_den_Linden "Unter den Linden"). There are also 86 public libraries in the city.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-berlin.de-148)^ [ResearchGate](/wiki/ResearchGate "ResearchGate"), a global social networking site for scientists, is based in Berlin.{#cite_ref-berlin.de_148-4}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: Culture")\]  
Main article: [Culture in Berlin](/wiki/Culture_in_Berlin "Culture in Berlin")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Alte_Nationalgalerie_abends_%28Zuschnitt%29.jpg/220px-Alte_Nationalgalerie_abends_%28Zuschnitt%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Alte_Nationalgalerie_abends_(Zuschnitt).jpg) The [Alte Nationalgalerie](/wiki/Alte_Nationalgalerie "Alte Nationalgalerie") is part of the [Museum Island](/wiki/Museum_Island "Museum Island"), a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site").

Berlin is known for its numerous cultural institutions, many of which enjoy international reputation.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-UNESCO-25)^^[\[221\]](#cite_note-UNESCO-2-221)^ The diversity and vivacity of the metropolis led to a trendsetting atmosphere.^[\[222\]](#cite_note-222)^ An innovative music, dance and art scene has developed in the 21st century.{#cite_ref-222}

Young people, international artists and entrepreneurs continued to settle in the city and made Berlin a popular entertainment center in the world.^[\[223\]](#cite_note-223)^{#cite_ref-223}

The expanding cultural performance of the city was underscored by the relocation of the [Universal Music Group](/wiki/Universal_Music_Group "Universal Music Group") who decided to move their headquarters to the banks of the River Spree.^[\[224\]](#cite_note-224)^ In 2005, Berlin was named "City of Design" by [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") and has been part of the [Creative Cities Network](/wiki/Creative_Cities_Network "Creative Cities Network") ever since.^[\[225\]](#cite_note-225)^^[\[22\]](#cite_note-UNESCO-2005-22)^{#cite_ref-UNESCO-2005_22-1}

Many German and International films were shot in Berlin, including *[M](/wiki/M_(1931_film) "M (1931 film)")* , *[One, Two, Three](/wiki/One,_Two,_Three "One, Two, Three")* , *[Cabaret](/wiki/Cabaret_(1972_film) "Cabaret (1972 film)")* , *[Christiane F.](/wiki/Christiane_F._(film) "Christiane F. (film)")* , *[Possession](/wiki/Possession_(1981_film) "Possession (1981 film)")* , *[Octopussy](/wiki/Octopussy "Octopussy")* , *[Wings of Desire](/wiki/Wings_of_Desire "Wings of Desire")* , *[Run Lola Run](/wiki/Run_Lola_Run "Run Lola Run")* , *[The Bourne Trilogy](/wiki/Bourne_(film_series) "Bourne (film series)")* , *[Good Bye, Lenin!](/wiki/Good_Bye,_Lenin! "Good Bye, Lenin!")* , *[The Lives of Others](/wiki/The_Lives_of_Others "The Lives of Others")* , *[Inglourious Basterds](/wiki/Inglourious_Basterds "Inglourious Basterds")* , *[Hanna](/wiki/Hanna_(film) "Hanna (film)")* , *[Unknown](/wiki/Unknown_(2011_film) "Unknown (2011 film)")* and *[Bridge of Spies](/wiki/Bridge_of_Spies_(film) "Bridge of Spies (film)")*.  

### Galleries and museums {#Galleries_and_museums}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Galleries and museums")\]  
For a more comprehensive list, see [List of museums and galleries in Berlin](/wiki/List_of_museums_and_galleries_in_Berlin "List of museums and galleries in Berlin").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Nofretete_Neues_Museum.jpg/170px-Nofretete_Neues_Museum.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nofretete_Neues_Museum.jpg) [Thutmose](/wiki/Thutmose_(sculptor) "Thutmose (sculptor)"), *[Bust of Nefertiti](/wiki/Bust_of_Nefertiti "Bust of Nefertiti")* , 1345 BCE, [Egyptian Museum of Berlin](/wiki/Egyptian_Museum_of_Berlin "Egyptian Museum of Berlin")

As of 2011^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit)^ Berlin is home to 138 museums and more than 400 art galleries.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-berlin.de-148)^^[\[226\]](#cite_note-226)^ The ensemble on the [Museum Island](/wiki/Museum_Island "Museum Island") is a UNESCO [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") and is in the northern part of the Spree Island between the Spree and the Kupfergraben.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-UNESCO-25)^ As early as 1841 it was designated a "district dedicated to art and antiquities" by a royal decree. Subsequently, the [Altes Museum](/wiki/Altes_Museum "Altes Museum") was built in the Lustgarten. The [Neues Museum](/wiki/Neues_Museum "Neues Museum"), which displays the [bust of Queen Nefertiti](/wiki/Nefertiti_Bust "Nefertiti Bust"),^[\[227\]](#cite_note-227)^ [Alte Nationalgalerie](/wiki/Alte_Nationalgalerie "Alte Nationalgalerie"), [Pergamon Museum](/wiki/Pergamon_Museum "Pergamon Museum"), and [Bode Museum](/wiki/Bode_Museum "Bode Museum") were built there.{#cite_ref-227}

Apart from the Museum Island, there are many additional museums in the city. The [Gemäldegalerie](/wiki/Gem%C3%A4ldegalerie,_Berlin "Gemäldegalerie, Berlin") (Painting Gallery) focuses on the paintings of the "old masters" from the 13th to the 18th centuries, while the [Neue Nationalgalerie](/wiki/Neue_Nationalgalerie "Neue Nationalgalerie") (New National Gallery, built by [Ludwig Mies van der Rohe](/wiki/Ludwig_Mies_van_der_Rohe "Ludwig Mies van der Rohe")) specializes in 20th-century European painting. The [Hamburger Bahnhof](/wiki/Hamburger_Bahnhof "Hamburger Bahnhof"), in [Moabit](/wiki/Moabit "Moabit"), exhibits a major collection of modern and contemporary art. The expanded [Deutsches Historisches Museum](/wiki/Deutsches_Historisches_Museum "Deutsches Historisches Museum") reopened in the Zeughaus with an overview of German history spanning more than a millennium. The [Bauhaus Archive](/wiki/Bauhaus_Archive "Bauhaus Archive") is a museum of 20th-century design from the famous [Bauhaus](/wiki/Bauhaus "Bauhaus") school. [Museum Berggruen](/wiki/Museum_Berggruen "Museum Berggruen") houses the collection of noted 20th century collector [Heinz Berggruen](/wiki/Heinz_Berggruen "Heinz Berggruen"), and features an extensive assortment of works by [Picasso](/wiki/Picasso "Picasso"), [Matisse](/wiki/Matisse "Matisse"), [Cézanne](/wiki/C%C3%A9zanne "Cézanne"), and [Giacometti](/wiki/Giacometti "Giacometti"), among others.^[\[228\]](#cite_note-228)^ The [Kupferstichkabinett](/wiki/Kupferstichkabinett_Berlin "Kupferstichkabinett Berlin") Berlin (Museum of Prints and Drawings) is part of the [Staatlichen Museen zu Berlin](/wiki/Berlin_State_Museums "Berlin State Museums") (Berlin State Museums) and the [Kulturforum at Potsdamer Platz](/wiki/Kulturforum "Kulturforum") in the Tiergarten district of Berlin's Mitte district. It is the largest museum of the graphic arts in Germany and at the same time one of the four most important collections of its kind in the world.^[\[229\]](#cite_note-229)^ The collection includes [Friedrich Gilly](/wiki/Friedrich_Gilly "Friedrich Gilly")'s design for the monument to Frederick II of Prussia.^[\[230\]](#cite_note-230)^{#cite_ref-230}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Ishtar_Gate_at_Berlin_Museum.jpg/220px-Ishtar_Gate_at_Berlin_Museum.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ishtar_Gate_at_Berlin_Museum.jpg) The reconstructed [Ishtar Gate](/wiki/Ishtar_Gate "Ishtar Gate") of Babylon at the [Pergamon Museum](/wiki/Pergamon_Museum "Pergamon Museum") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/JewishMuseumBerlin.jpg/220px-JewishMuseumBerlin.jpg)](/wiki/File:JewishMuseumBerlin.jpg) The [Jewish Museum](/wiki/Jewish_Museum_Berlin "Jewish Museum Berlin") presents two millennia of [German--Jewish history](/wiki/German_Jews "German Jews").

The [Jewish Museum](/wiki/Jewish_Museum_Berlin "Jewish Museum Berlin") has a standing exhibition on two millennia of German-Jewish history.^[\[231\]](#cite_note-231)^ The [German Museum of Technology](/wiki/German_Museum_of_Technology_(Berlin) "German Museum of Technology (Berlin)") in [Kreuzberg](/wiki/Kreuzberg "Kreuzberg") has a large collection of historical technical artifacts. The *[Museum für Naturkunde](/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_Berlin "Natural History Museum, Berlin")* (Berlin's [natural history museum](/wiki/Natural_history_museum "Natural history museum")) exhibits [natural history](/wiki/Natural_history "Natural history") near [Berlin Hauptbahnhof](/wiki/Berlin_Hauptbahnhof "Berlin Hauptbahnhof"). It has the largest mounted dinosaur in the world (a *[Giraffatitan](/wiki/Giraffatitan "Giraffatitan")* skeleton). A well-preserved specimen of *[Tyrannosaurus rex](/wiki/Tyrannosaurus "Tyrannosaurus")* and the early bird *[Archaeopteryx](/wiki/Archaeopteryx "Archaeopteryx")* are at display as well.^[\[232\]](#cite_note-232)^{#cite_ref-232}

In [Dahlem](/wiki/Dahlem_(Berlin) "Dahlem (Berlin)"), there are several museums of world art and culture, such as the [Museum of Asian Art](/wiki/Museum_of_Asian_Art "Museum of Asian Art"), the [Ethnological Museum](/wiki/Ethnological_Museum_of_Berlin "Ethnological Museum of Berlin"), the [Museum of European Cultures](/wiki/Museum_Europ%C3%A4ischer_Kulturen "Museum Europäischer Kulturen"), as well as the [Allied Museum](/wiki/Allied_Museum "Allied Museum"). The [Brücke Museum](/wiki/Br%C3%BCcke_Museum "Brücke Museum") features one of the largest collection of works by artist of the early 20th-century expressionist movement. In [Lichtenberg](/wiki/Lichtenberg "Lichtenberg"), on the grounds of the former [East German Ministry for State Security](/wiki/Stasi "Stasi"), is the [Stasi Museum](/wiki/Stasi_Museum "Stasi Museum"). The site of [Checkpoint Charlie](/wiki/Checkpoint_Charlie "Checkpoint Charlie"), one of the most renowned crossing points of the Berlin Wall, is still preserved. A private [museum venture](/wiki/Checkpoint_Charlie_Museum "Checkpoint Charlie Museum") exhibits a comprehensive documentation of detailed plans and strategies devised by people who tried to flee from the East.

The [Beate Uhse Erotic Museum](/wiki/Beate_Uhse_Erotic_Museum "Beate Uhse Erotic Museum") claimed to be the largest erotic museum in the world until it closed in 2014.^[\[233\]](#cite_note-233)^^[\[234\]](#cite_note-234)^{#cite_ref-234}

The cityscape of Berlin displays large quantities of urban [street art](/wiki/Street_art "Street art").^[\[235\]](#cite_note-235)^ It has become a significant part of the city's cultural heritage and has its roots in the graffiti scene of [Kreuzberg](/wiki/Kreuzberg "Kreuzberg") of the 1980s.^[\[236\]](#cite_note-236)^ The [Berlin Wall](/wiki/Berlin_Wall_graffiti_art "Berlin Wall graffiti art") itself has become one of the largest open-air canvasses in the world.^[\[237\]](#cite_note-237)^ The leftover stretch along the Spree river in [Friedrichshain](/wiki/Friedrichshain "Friedrichshain") remains as the [East Side Gallery](/wiki/East_Side_Gallery "East Side Gallery"). Berlin today is consistently rated as an important world city for street art culture.^[\[238\]](#cite_note-238)^ Berlin has galleries which are quite rich in contemporary art. Located in Mitte, KW Institute for Contemporary Art, KOW, Sprüth Magers; Kreuzberg there are a few galleries as well such as Blain Southern, [Esther Schipper](/wiki/Esther_Schipper "Esther Schipper"), Future Gallery, König Gallerie.{#cite_ref-238}  

### Nightlife and festivals {#Nightlife_and_festivals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=48 "Edit section: Nightlife and festivals")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/20150208_-_Berlinale_Palast_and_Red_Carpet.JPG/220px-20150208_-_Berlinale_Palast_and_Red_Carpet.JPG)](/wiki/File:20150208_-_Berlinale_Palast_and_Red_Carpet.JPG) The [Berlinale](/wiki/Berlinale "Berlinale") is the world's largest international spectator film festival.

Berlin's nightlife has been celebrated as one of the most diverse and vibrant of its kind.^[\[239\]](#cite_note-239)^^[\[240\]](#cite_note-240)^ In the 1970s and 80s, the [SO36](/wiki/SO36 "SO36") in [Kreuzberg](/wiki/Kreuzberg "Kreuzberg") was a center for [punk music](/wiki/Punk_music "Punk music") and culture. The *SOUND* and the *Dschungel* gained notoriety. Throughout the 1990s, people in their 20s from all over the world, particularly those in [Western](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe") and Central Europe, made Berlin's club scene a premier nightlife venue. After the [fall of the Berlin Wall](/wiki/Fall_of_the_Berlin_Wall "Fall of the Berlin Wall") in 1989, many historic buildings in Mitte, the former city center of East Berlin, were illegally occupied and re-built by young squatters and became a fertile ground for underground and [counterculture](/wiki/Counterculture "Counterculture") gatherings.^[\[241\]](#cite_note-241)^ The central boroughs are home to many nightclubs, including the [Tresor](/wiki/Tresor_(club) "Tresor (club)") and the [Berghain](/wiki/Berghain "Berghain"). The [KitKatClub](/wiki/KitKatClub "KitKatClub") and several other locations are known for their sexually uninhibited parties.{#cite_ref-241}

Clubs are not required to close at a fixed time during the weekends, and many parties last well into the morning or even all weekend, including near [Alexanderplatz](/wiki/Alexanderplatz "Alexanderplatz"). Several venues have become a popular stage for the [Neo-Burlesque](/wiki/Neo-Burlesque "Neo-Burlesque") scene.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Festival_of_Lights_2012_-_Franz%C3%B6sischer_Dom.jpg/220px-Festival_of_Lights_2012_-_Franz%C3%B6sischer_Dom.jpg)](/wiki/File:Festival_of_Lights_2012_-_Franz%C3%B6sischer_Dom.jpg) The [French Cathedral](/wiki/French_Cathedral,_Berlin "French Cathedral, Berlin") during the annual [Festival of Lights](/wiki/Festival_of_Lights_(Berlin) "Festival of Lights (Berlin)") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Hanukkah%2C_Brandenburg_Gate_%28Berlin%29.jpg/220px-Hanukkah%2C_Brandenburg_Gate_%28Berlin%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hanukkah,_Brandenburg_Gate_(Berlin).jpg) [Hanukkah](/wiki/Hanukkah "Hanukkah") festival at the Brandenburg Gate

Berlin has a long history of gay culture, and is an important [birthplace of the LGBT rights movement](/wiki/Scientific-Humanitarian_Committee "Scientific-Humanitarian Committee"). Same-sex bars and dance halls operated freely as early as the 1880s, and the first gay magazine, *Der Eigene* , started in 1896. By the 1920s, gays and lesbians had an unprecedented visibility.^[\[242\]](#cite_note-242)^^[\[243\]](#cite_note-243)^ Today, in addition to a positive atmosphere in the wider club scene, the city again has a huge number of queer clubs and festivals. The most famous and largest are [Berlin Pride](/wiki/Berlin_Pride "Berlin Pride"), the [Christopher Street Day](/wiki/Christopher_Street_Day "Christopher Street Day"),^[\[244\]](#cite_note-244)^ the [Lesbian and Gay City Festival](/wiki/Lesbian_and_Gay_City_Festival "Lesbian and Gay City Festival") in Berlin-Schöneberg, the [Kreuzberg Pride](/wiki/Kreuzberg_Pride "Kreuzberg Pride").{#cite_ref-244}

The annual [Berlin International Film Festival](/wiki/Berlin_International_Film_Festival "Berlin International Film Festival") (Berlinale) with around 500,000 admissions is considered to be the largest publicly attended film festival in the world.^[\[245\]](#cite_note-245)^^[\[246\]](#cite_note-246)^ The Karneval der Kulturen (*Carnival of Cultures* ), a multi-ethnic street parade, is celebrated every [Pentecost](/wiki/Pentecost "Pentecost") weekend.^[\[247\]](#cite_note-247)^ Berlin is also well known for the cultural festival [Berliner Festspiele](/wiki/Berliner_Festspiele "Berliner Festspiele"), which includes the jazz festival [JazzFest Berlin](/wiki/JazzFest_Berlin "JazzFest Berlin"), and [Young Euro Classic](/wiki/Young_Euro_Classic "Young Euro Classic"), the largest international festival of [youth orchestras](/wiki/Youth_orchestra "Youth orchestra") in the world. Several technology and media art festivals and conferences are held in the city, including [Transmediale](/wiki/Transmediale "Transmediale") and [Chaos Communication Congress](/wiki/Chaos_Communication_Congress "Chaos Communication Congress"). The annual [Berlin Festival](/wiki/Berlin_Festival "Berlin Festival") focuses on indie rock, electronic music and synthpop and is part of the International Berlin Music Week.^[\[248\]](#cite_note-248)^^[\[249\]](#cite_note-249)^ Every year Berlin hosts one of the largest New Year's Eve celebrations in the world, attended by well over a million people. The focal point is the Brandenburg Gate, where midnight fireworks are centered, but various private fireworks displays take place throughout the entire city. Partygoers in Germany often toast the New Year with a glass of [sparkling wine](/wiki/Sekt "Sekt").{#cite_ref-249}  

### Performing arts {#Performing_arts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=49 "Edit section: Performing arts")\]  
Main article: [Music in Berlin](/wiki/Music_in_Berlin "Music in Berlin")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Rattle_BPH-Rittershaus1-Wikipedia.jpg/220px-Rattle_BPH-Rittershaus1-Wikipedia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rattle_BPH-Rittershaus1-Wikipedia.jpg) Sir [Simon Rattle](/wiki/Simon_Rattle "Simon Rattle") conducting the renowned [Berlin Philharmonic](/wiki/Berlin_Philharmonic "Berlin Philharmonic")

Berlin is home to 44 theaters and stages.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-berlin.de-148)^ The [Deutsches Theater](/wiki/Deutsches_Theater_(Berlin) "Deutsches Theater (Berlin)") in Mitte was built in 1849--50 and has operated almost continuously since then. The [Volksbühne](/wiki/Volksb%C3%BChne "Volksbühne") at [Rosa-Luxemburg-Platz](/wiki/Rosa-Luxemburg-Platz "Rosa-Luxemburg-Platz") was built in 1913--14, though the company had been founded in 1890. The [Berliner Ensemble](/wiki/Berliner_Ensemble "Berliner Ensemble"), famous for performing the works of [Bertolt Brecht](/wiki/Bertolt_Brecht "Bertolt Brecht"), was established in 1949. The [Schaubühne](/wiki/Schaub%C3%BChne "Schaubühne") was founded in 1962 and moved to the building of the former Universum Cinema on Kurfürstendamm in 1981. With a [seating capacity](/wiki/Seating_capacity "Seating capacity") of 1,895 and a stage floor of 2,854 square meters (30,720 sq ft), the [Friedrichstadt-Palast](/wiki/Friedrichstadt-Palast "Friedrichstadt-Palast") in Berlin Mitte is the largest show palace in Europe. For Berlin's independent dance and theatre scene, venues such as the Sophiensäle in Mitte and the three houses of the [Hebbel am Ufer (HAU)](/wiki/Hebbel-Theater "Hebbel-Theater") in Kreuzberg are important. Most productions there are also accessible to an English-speaking audience. Some of the dance and theatre groups that also work internationally ([Gob Squad](/wiki/Gob_Squad "Gob Squad"), [Rimini Protokoll](/wiki/Rimini_Protokoll "Rimini Protokoll")) are based there, as well as festivals such as the international festival [Dance in August](/wiki/Tanz_im_August "Tanz im August").{#cite_ref-berlin.de_148-6}

Berlin has three major [opera houses](/wiki/Opera_house "Opera house"): the [Deutsche Oper](/wiki/Deutsche_Oper "Deutsche Oper"), the [Berlin State Opera](/wiki/Berlin_State_Opera "Berlin State Opera"), and the [Komische Oper](/wiki/Komische_Oper "Komische Oper"). The Berlin State Opera on [Unter den Linden](/wiki/Unter_den_Linden "Unter den Linden") opened in 1742 and is the oldest of the three. Its musical director is [Daniel Barenboim](/wiki/Daniel_Barenboim "Daniel Barenboim"). The Komische Oper has traditionally specialized in [operettas](/wiki/Operetta "Operetta") and is also at Unter den Linden. The Deutsche Oper opened in 1912 in Charlottenburg.

The city's main venue for musical theater performances are the Theater am Potsdamer Platz and [Theater des Westens](/wiki/Theater_des_Westens "Theater des Westens") (built in 1895). Contemporary dance can be seen at the *Radialsystem V* . The [Tempodrom](/wiki/Tempodrom "Tempodrom") is host to concerts and circus-inspired entertainment. It also houses a multi-sensory spa experience. The [Admiralspalast](/wiki/Admiralspalast "Admiralspalast") in Mitte has a vibrant program of variety and music events.

There are seven symphony orchestras in Berlin. The [Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra](/wiki/Berlin_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra") is one of the preeminent orchestras in the world;^[\[250\]](#cite_note-250)^ it is housed in the [Berliner Philharmonie](/wiki/Berliner_Philharmonie "Berliner Philharmonie") near Potsdamer Platz on a street named for the orchestra's longest-serving conductor, [Herbert von Karajan](/wiki/Herbert_von_Karajan "Herbert von Karajan").^[\[251\]](#cite_note-251)^ [Simon Rattle](/wiki/Simon_Rattle "Simon Rattle") was its principal conductor from 1999 to 2018, a position now held by [Kirill Petrenko](/wiki/Kirill_Petrenko "Kirill Petrenko"). The [Konzerthausorchester Berlin](/wiki/Konzerthausorchester_Berlin "Konzerthausorchester Berlin") was founded in 1952 as the orchestra for East Berlin. [Christoph Eschenbach](/wiki/Christoph_Eschenbach "Christoph Eschenbach") is its principal conductor. The [Haus der Kulturen der Welt](/wiki/Haus_der_Kulturen_der_Welt "Haus der Kulturen der Welt") presents exhibitions dealing with intercultural issues and stages world music and conferences.^[\[252\]](#cite_note-252)^ The *Kookaburra* and the *Quatsch Comedy Club* are known for satire and comedy shows. In 2018, the *[New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")* described Berlin as "arguably the world capital of underground [electronic music](/wiki/Electronic_music "Electronic music")".^[\[253\]](#cite_note-253)^{#cite_ref-253}  

### Cuisine {#Cuisine}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=50 "Edit section: Cuisine")\]  
Main article: [Cuisine of Berlin](/wiki/Cuisine_of_Berlin "Cuisine of Berlin")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/D%C3%B6ner_Kebab.jpg/226px-D%C3%B6ner_Kebab.jpg)](/wiki/File:D%C3%B6ner_Kebab.jpg)  
[Döner kebab](/wiki/Doner_kebab "Doner kebab")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Currywurst-1.jpg/192px-Currywurst-1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Currywurst-1.jpg)  
A plate of [Currywurst](/wiki/Currywurst "Currywurst")  
Invented in Berlin, currywurst and modern döner are icons of German popular culture and cuisine.

The [cuisine](/wiki/German_cuisine "German cuisine") and culinary offerings of Berlin vary greatly. 23 restaurants in Berlin have been awarded one or more [Michelin stars](/wiki/Michelin_Guide#Stars "Michelin Guide") in the [Michelin Guide](/wiki/Michelin_Guide "Michelin Guide") of 2021, which ranks the city at the top for the number of restaurants having this distinction in Germany.^[\[254\]](#cite_note-254)^ Berlin is well known for its offerings of vegetarian^[\[255\]](#cite_note-255)^ and [vegan](/wiki/Veganism "Veganism")^[\[256\]](#cite_note-256)^ cuisine and is home to an innovative entrepreneurial food scene promoting cosmopolitan flavors, local and sustainable ingredients, pop-up street food markets, supper clubs, as well as food festivals, such as Berlin Food Week.^[\[257\]](#cite_note-257)^^[\[258\]](#cite_note-258)^{#cite_ref-258}

Many local foods originated from north German culinary traditions and include rustic and hearty dishes with pork, goose, fish, peas, beans, cucumbers, or potatoes. Typical Berliner fare include popular [street food](/wiki/Street_food "Street food") like the *[Currywurst](/wiki/Currywurst "Currywurst")* (which gained popularity with postwar construction workers rebuilding the city), *[Buletten](/wiki/Frikadeller "Frikadeller")* and the *[Berliner](/wiki/Berliner_(doughnut) "Berliner (doughnut)")* donut, known in Berlin as *Pfannkuchen* (
German: [\[ˈp͡fanˌkuːxn̩\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Standard_German "Help:IPA/Standard German") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/9/99/De-Pfannkuchen.ogg/De-Pfannkuchen.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:De-Pfannkuchen.ogg "File:De-Pfannkuchen.ogg")^).^[\[259\]](#cite_note-259)^^[\[260\]](#cite_note-260)^ German bakeries offering a variety of breads and pastries are widespread. One of Europe's largest [delicatessen](/wiki/Delicatessen "Delicatessen") markets is found at the [KaDeWe](/wiki/KaDeWe "KaDeWe"), and among the world's largest chocolate stores is *Rausch* .^[\[261\]](#cite_note-261)^^[\[262\]](#cite_note-262)^{#cite_ref-262}

Berlin is also home to a diverse gastronomy scene reflecting the immigrant history of the city. Turkish and Arab immigrants brought their culinary traditions to the city, such as the [lahmajoun](/wiki/Lahmajoun "Lahmajoun") and [falafel](/wiki/Falafel "Falafel"), which have become common fast food staples. The modern fast-food version of the [doner kebab](/wiki/Doner_kebab "Doner kebab") sandwich which [evolved in Berlin](/wiki/Kadir_Nurman "Kadir Nurman") in the 1970s, has since become a favorite dish in Germany and elsewhere in the world.^[\[263\]](#cite_note-263)^ Asian cuisine like Chinese, Vietnamese, Thai, Indian, Korean, and Japanese restaurants, as well as Spanish tapas bars, Italian, and Greek cuisine, can be found in many parts of the city.{#cite_ref-263}  

### Recreation {#Recreation}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=51 "Edit section: Recreation")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Berlin_Elefantentor_09-2017.jpg/220px-Berlin_Elefantentor_09-2017.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin_Elefantentor_09-2017.jpg) The Elephant Gate at the [Berlin Zoo](/wiki/Berlin_Zoological_Garden "Berlin Zoological Garden")

[Zoologischer Garten Berlin](/wiki/Berlin_Zoological_Garden "Berlin Zoological Garden"), the older of two zoos in the city, was founded in 1844. It is the most visited zoo in Europe and presents the most diverse range of species in the world.^[\[264\]](#cite_note-264)^ It was the home of the captive-born celebrity polar bear [Knut](/wiki/Knut_(polar_bear) "Knut (polar bear)").^[\[265\]](#cite_note-265)^ The city's other zoo, [Tierpark Friedrichsfelde](/wiki/Tierpark_Berlin "Tierpark Berlin"), was founded in 1955.{#cite_ref-265}

[Berlin's Botanischer Garten](/wiki/Berlin-Dahlem_Botanical_Garden_and_Botanical_Museum "Berlin-Dahlem Botanical Garden and Botanical Museum") includes the Botanic Museum Berlin. With an area of 43 hectares (110 acres) and around 22,000 different plant species, it is one of the largest and most diverse collections of botanical life in the world. Other gardens in the city include the [Britzer Garten](/wiki/Britzer_Garten "Britzer Garten"), and the [Gärten der Welt](/wiki/Erholungspark_Marzahn "Erholungspark Marzahn") (Gardens of the World) in Marzahn.^[\[266\]](#cite_note-266)^{#cite_ref-266}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Siegess%C3%A4ule10_b.jpg/220px-Siegess%C3%A4ule10_b.jpg)](/wiki/File:Siegess%C3%A4ule10_b.jpg) The [Victory Column](/wiki/Berlin_Victory_Column "Berlin Victory Column") in [Tiergarten](/wiki/Tiergarten_(park) "Tiergarten (park)")

The [Tiergarten park](/wiki/Tiergarten_(park) "Tiergarten (park)") in Mitte, with landscape design by [Peter Joseph Lenné](/wiki/Peter_Joseph_Lenn%C3%A9 "Peter Joseph Lenné"), is one of Berlin's largest and most popular parks.^[\[267\]](#cite_note-267)^ In Kreuzberg, the [Viktoriapark](/wiki/Viktoriapark "Viktoriapark") provides a viewing point over the southern part of inner-city Berlin. [Treptower Park](/wiki/Treptower_Park "Treptower Park"), beside the Spree in [Treptow](/wiki/Treptow "Treptow"), features a large [Soviet War Memorial](/wiki/Soviet_War_Memorial_(Treptower_Park) "Soviet War Memorial (Treptower Park)"). The Volkspark in [Friedrichshain](/wiki/Friedrichshain "Friedrichshain"), which opened in 1848, is the oldest park in the city, with monuments, a summer outdoor cinema and several sports areas.^[\[268\]](#cite_note-268)^ [Tempelhofer Feld](/wiki/Tempelhofer_Feld "Tempelhofer Feld"), the site of the former [city airport](/wiki/Berlin_Tempelhof_Airport "Berlin Tempelhof Airport"), is the world's largest inner-city open space.^[\[269\]](#cite_note-269)^{#cite_ref-269}

[Potsdam](/wiki/Potsdam "Potsdam") is on the southwestern periphery of Berlin. The city was a residence of the [Prussian](/wiki/Prussia "Prussia") kings and the [German Kaiser](/wiki/German_Emperor "German Emperor"), until 1918. The area around Potsdam in particular [Sanssouci](/wiki/Sanssouci "Sanssouci") is known for a series of interconnected lakes and cultural landmarks. The [Palaces and Parks of Potsdam and Berlin](/wiki/Palaces_and_Parks_of_Potsdam_and_Berlin "Palaces and Parks of Potsdam and Berlin") are the largest [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") in Germany.^[\[221\]](#cite_note-UNESCO-2-221)^{#cite_ref-UNESCO-2_221-1}

Berlin is also well known for its numerous cafés, street musicians, beach bars along the Spree River, flea markets, boutique shops and [pop-up stores](/wiki/Pop-up_store "Pop-up store"), which are a source for recreation and leisure.^[\[270\]](#cite_note-270)^{#cite_ref-270}  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=52 "Edit section: Sports")\]  
Main article: [Sport in Berlin](/wiki/Sport_in_Berlin "Sport in Berlin")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Berliner_Olympiastadion_night_2.jpg/220px-Berliner_Olympiastadion_night_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berliner_Olympiastadion_night_2.jpg) The [Olympiastadion](/wiki/Olympic_Stadium_(Berlin) "Olympic Stadium (Berlin)") hosted the [1936 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1936_Summer_Olympics "1936 Summer Olympics") and the [2006 FIFA World Cup final](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup_final "2006 FIFA World Cup final"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Berlin_marathon.jpg/220px-Berlin_marathon.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin_marathon.jpg) The [Berlin Marathon](/wiki/Berlin_Marathon "Berlin Marathon") is the current second world record course (world record course is as of August 2024^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit)^ [Chicago Marathon](/wiki/Chicago_Marathon "Chicago Marathon")). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Berlin_Mercedes-Benz-Arena.jpg/220px-Berlin_Mercedes-Benz-Arena.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin_Mercedes-Benz-Arena.jpg) [Uber Arena](/wiki/Uber_Arena "Uber Arena") (formerly Mercedes-Benz Arena)

Berlin has established a high-profile as a host city of major international sporting events.^[\[271\]](#cite_note-271)^ The city hosted the [1936 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1936_Summer_Olympics "1936 Summer Olympics") and was the host city for the [2006 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup") final.^[\[272\]](#cite_note-272)^ The [World Athletics Championships](/wiki/World_Athletics_Championships "World Athletics Championships") was held at [Olympiastadion](/wiki/Olympiastadion_(Berlin) "Olympiastadion (Berlin)") in [2009](/wiki/2009_World_Athletics_Championships "2009 World Athletics Championships") and [2025](/wiki/2025_World_Athletics_Championships "2025 World Athletics Championships").^[\[273\]](#cite_note-273)^ The city hosted the [Euroleague Final Four](/wiki/Euroleague_Final_Four "Euroleague Final Four") basketball competition in [2009](/wiki/2009_Euroleague_Final_Four "2009 Euroleague Final Four") and [2016](/wiki/2016_Euroleague_Final_Four "2016 Euroleague Final Four"),^[\[274\]](#cite_note-274)^ and was one of the hosts of FIBA [EuroBasket 2015](/wiki/EuroBasket_2015 "EuroBasket 2015"). In 2015 Berlin was the venue for the [UEFA Champions League Final](/wiki/2015_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2015 UEFA Champions League Final"). The city bid to host the [2000 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics "2000 Summer Olympics") but lost to [Sydney](/wiki/Sydney "Sydney").^[\[275\]](#cite_note-275)^{#cite_ref-275}

Berlin hosted the [2023 Special Olympics World Summer Games](/wiki/2023_Special_Olympics_World_Summer_Games "2023 Special Olympics World Summer Games"). This is the first time Germany has ever hosted the Special Olympics World Games.^[\[276\]](#cite_note-276)^{#cite_ref-276}

The annual [Berlin Marathon](/wiki/Berlin_Marathon "Berlin Marathon") -- a course that holds the most top-10 world record runs -- and the [ISTAF](/wiki/Internationales_Stadionfest "Internationales Stadionfest") are well-established athletic events in the city.^[\[277\]](#cite_note-277)^ The [Mellowpark](/wiki/Mellowpark "Mellowpark") in Köpenick is one of the biggest skate and BMX parks in Europe.^[\[278\]](#cite_note-278)^ A fan fest at Brandenburg Gate, which attracts several hundreds of thousands of spectators, has become popular during international football competitions, such as the [UEFA European Championship](/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship "UEFA European Championship").^[\[279\]](#cite_note-279)^{#cite_ref-279}

[Friedrich Ludwig Jahn](/wiki/Friedrich_Ludwig_Jahn "Friedrich Ludwig Jahn"), who is often hailed as the "father of modern gymnastics", invented the [horizontal bar](/wiki/Horizontal_bar "Horizontal bar"), [parallel bars](/wiki/Parallel_bars "Parallel bars"), [rings](/wiki/Rings_(gymnastics) "Rings (gymnastics)"), and the [vault](/wiki/Vault_(gymnastics) "Vault (gymnastics)") around 1811 in Berlin.^[\[280\]](#cite_note-280)^^[\[281\]](#cite_note-281)^^[\[282\]](#cite_note-282)^ Jahn's [Turners](/wiki/Turners "Turners") movement, first realized at [Volkspark Hasenheide](/wiki/Volkspark_Hasenheide "Volkspark Hasenheide"), was the origin of modern [sports clubs](/wiki/Sports_clubs "Sports clubs").^[\[283\]](#cite_note-283)^ In 2013, around 600,000 Berliners were registered in one of the more than 2,300 sport and fitness clubs.^[\[284\]](#cite_note-284)^ The city of Berlin operates more than 60 public indoor and outdoor swimming pools.^[\[285\]](#cite_note-285)^ Berlin is the largest Olympic training center in Germany, with around 500 top athletes (15% of all German top athletes) being based there. Forty-seven elite athletes participated in the 2012 Summer Olympics. Berliners would achieve seven gold, twelve silver, and three bronze medals.^[\[286\]](#cite_note-286)^{#cite_ref-286}

Several professional clubs representing the most important spectator team sports in Germany are based in Berlin. The oldest and most popular first-division team based in Berlin is the football club [Hertha BSC](/wiki/Hertha_BSC "Hertha BSC").^[\[287\]](#cite_note-Herthabsc.de-2011-287)^ The team represented Berlin as a founding member of the [Bundesliga](/wiki/Bundesliga "Bundesliga") in 1963.
